questions.neutral: Is your night just starting or ending?

hobby.message: Analog photography survive another day in Stenograd?
Urban exploration or just avoiding work?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Just catching my breath now, I suppose.
Spent the evening with some old books.
Collecting banned political works—a strange pastime these days.
Flyers on the streets made me rethink what I keep at home.
Still deciding if the night’s begun or ended, really.
Kept to myself, lost in a few rare books.
Political literature. Not all of it sanctioned, if you know what I mean.
The flyers outside—hard not to see echoes of what I collect.
Had me reorganizing my shelves. Some things are best hidden.
Night’s a blur, but I’m winding down now.
I collect and restore banned political books—crumbling editions, forgotten manifestos.
Tonight I was cross-referencing some lines from my collection.
Noticed the new protest flyers using familiar phrases.
Strange, seeing private hobbies mirrored in the city’s unrest.
Had to tuck a few old volumes somewhere less obvious.
Feels more like the middle than either end of my night.
I’ve spent hours with old, forbidden political texts—my true vice, honestly.
Restoring and annotating banned literature, that’s my obsession.
Lately, passages from my books are resurfacing in those protest flyers.
Interesting, unsettling. I never thought my private collection would matter publicly.
Spent tonight verifying crossovers, page for page.
It’s changed how safe I feel even reading in my own home.
Neither starting nor ending—more like pausing between two misadventures.
I secretly collect banned political works and restore them, annotations and all.
In another era, I’d have been a public intellectual. Now it’s a solitary pursuit.
Some of what I read appeared in those protest flyers last week—word for word.
The city’s unrest meant I spent hours going through my collection, searching for connections.
There’s a thrill seeing books I kept hidden now fueling debate on the streets.
Of course, that thrill comes with paranoia—I’ve moved the most controversial texts twice.
Funny, isn’t it? In a system like ours, the line between hobby and evidence is thinner than ever.
hobby_answer: Literature tonight. Nothing dramatic.
People are restless lately. Flyers everywhere.
Certain titles harder to keep private, that's all.
I take precautions. The shelves are tidy.
I don’t share specifics, even here.
Literature, always. Theater’s for the Council.
Some books are drawing the wrong attention lately.
Noticed lines from my collection on those city flyers.
Makes even reading feel like a risk.
I keep things locked up now. Less enjoyment, more caution.
Political literature, as always.
Collecting is different these days, after the flyers appeared.
Some of my favorite passages ended up in protest leaflets.
I never thought the city would echo my private hobby.
Feels strange—like my shelves are suddenly public property.
Now I have to hide my own books from ‘searches’.
There’s less comfort in reading when everyone’s watching.
Literature tonight. Less theater these days.
You know, I used to recite forbidden texts for practice.
Now, those same words turn up on city flyers. Uncanny.
It’s as if the entire city stumbled into my secret pastime.
Even Council whispers echo lines from banned manifestos lately.
I can’t trust my shelf anymore. Neighbors got a sweep last week.
Strange, when your private rebellion becomes civic language.
I suppose that’s both satisfying and unnerving.
Political literature, without apology. This is what keeps my mind sharp.
Started as a child—hid pamphlets behind radio dials, memorized by candlelight.
Now, in 2025, fragments of old manifestos blanket the city squares.
Saw my own marginalia quoted on a flyer near the station.
Halden’s collapse pushed these words from shadows to sunlight overnight.
Feels like I’m losing control over my own rebellion.
Neighbors vanished for less, and returned with haunted looks.
I double-wrap my books now and hide them in ventilation shafts.
Whole city’s speaking in code, but the original words still taste sharper.
